content.p: This activity will take you through the movement of blood within the body’s circulation.
Click the next button to begin.

body.p: Imagine you are a red blood cell traveling through the Superior Vena Cava.

image.alt: image of the heart with an arrow indicating blood will flow through the Superior Vena Cava and into the heart.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Blood must travel through an atrium before arriving at its respective ventricle. Click to see the position of the Right Ventricle.

Incorrect. Oxygen-poor blood returns to the right side of the heart. Also, blood must travel through an atrium before arriving at its respective ventricle. Click to see the position of the Left Ventricle.
Correct. All the oxygen-poor blood from the systemic system returns to the right atrium. Click to see the position of the Right Atrium.
Incorrect. Oxygen-poor blood returns to the right side of the heart. Click to see the position of the Left Atrium.

part.hint: The superior vena cava returns deoxygenated blood from the upper half of the body to the heart.

image.alt: image of the heart with an arrow indicating blood will flow through the Superior Vena Cava and into the right atrium of the heart, which is the upper right chamber.

content.p: Oxygen-poor blood traveled from the Superior Vena Cava to the right atrium.

question.body: Which cardiac valve will the blood flow through next?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The aortic valve lies between the left ventricle and the aorta, where the blood exits the heart during ventricular systole. Click to see the position of the Aortic valve.
Incorrect. This valve lies between the left atrium and the left ventricle. Click to see the position of the Bicuspid (mitral) valve.
Incorrect. The pulmonary valve lies between the left ventricle and the pulmonary artery, opening during ventricular systole. Click to see the correct position of the Pulmonary valve.
Correct. This is the right atrio-ventricular valve between the right atrium and the right ventricle. Click to see the correct position of the Tricuspid valve.

part.hint: This valve is also known as the right atrioventricular valve, and leads to the right ventricle.

content.p: You are now in the Right Ventricle.

image.alt: image of the heart with an arrow indicating blood will flow from the right atrium of the heart, through Tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which is the lower right chamber.

question.body: As the ventricle goes into systole, through which valve will the blood flow next?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The aortic valve lies between the left ventricle and the aorta, where the blood exits the heart during ventricular systole. Click to see the position of the Aortic valve.
Incorrect. This valve lies between the left atrium and the left ventricle. Click to see the position of the Bicuspid (mitral) valve.

Correct. The pulmonary valve lies between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery, and opens during ventricular systole. The blood now flows away from the heart through the pulmonary trunk and right and left pulmonary arteries. Click to see the position of the Pulmonary valve.
Incorrect. The tricuspid valve shuts when ventricles go into systole, ensuring that blood does not flow backwards through the same valve. Click to see the position of the Tricuspid valve.

part.hint: Blood from the right side of the heart must be oxygenated before travelling to the left side of the heart.

question.body: What is happening outside the heart once the blood leaves through the pulmonary valve?

multiple_choice.choice: Blood is moving from vein to artery
Blood is exposed to pulmonary gas exchange

response.feedback: Incorrect. Blood does not flow directly from vein to artery.
Correct. The pulmonary vein contains oxygen-poor blood. Once the blood reaches the lungs via the pulmonary capillaries, oxygen-rich blood returns to the heart through the pulmonary veins.
Incorrect. The systemic circulation is involved in moving oxygen-rich blood away from the heart to the rest of the body.
Incorrect. Pressure would decrease, because as blood returns to the heart it flows from capillaries (smaller; high pressure) to the pulmonary vein (larger; low pressure).

part.hint: How does this deoxygenated blood receive oxygen to supply to tissues throughout the body?
The pulmonary vein is oxygen-poor while the pulmonary artery, which leads towards the heart, is oxygen-rich.

question.body: Now, which chamber of the heart does this oxygen-rich blood flow to?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Oxygen-poor blood from the right atrium flows to the right ventricle. Click to see the position of the Right Ventricle.
Incorrect. Click to see the position of the Left Ventricle.
Incorrect: Oxygen-poor blood from the systemic system returns to the right atrium. Click to see the position of the Right Atrium.
Correct: All the oxygen-rich blood returns here from the pulmonary capillaries after gas exchange. Click to see the position of the Left Atrium.

part.hint: The blood has just left the right side of the heart and become oxygenated. Where does it go next?

content.p: You are now in the left atrium.

image.alt: image of the heart with an arrow indicating blood will flow from the pulminary system back to the left atrium of the heart, which is the upper left chamber.

question.body: What valve does blood flow through upon atrial systole?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The aortic valve lies between the left ventricle and the aorta, where the blood exits the heart during ventricular systole. Click to see the position of the Aortic valve.
Correct. This valve lies between the left atrium and the left ventricle. Click to see the position of the Bicuspid (mitral) valve.
Incorrect. The pulmonary valve lies between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery, and opens during ventricular systole. Click to see the position of the Pulmonary valve.
Incorrect. The tricuspid valve is on the right side of the heart between the right atria and right ventricle. Click to see the position of the Tricuspid valve.

part.hint: This valve is also known as the left atrioventricular valve and leads to the left ventricle.

content.p: You are now in the left ventricle.

image.alt: image of the heart with an arrow indicating blood will flow from the left atrium of the heart, through the bicuspid valve into the left ventricle, which is the lower left chamber.

question.body: Which valve will the blood flow through during ventricular systole?

response.feedback: Correct. The aortic valve lies between the left ventricle and the aorta, where the blood exits the heart during ventricular systole. Aortic valve
Incorrect. This valve lies between the left atrium and the left ventricle. Bicuspid (mitral) valve
Incorrect. The pulmonary valve lies between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery. Pulmonary valve
Incorrect. The tricuspid valve is on the right side of the heart between the right atria and right ventricle. Tricuspid valve

part.hint: This valve is also known as the left atrioventricular valve and leads to the left ventricle.
